data.title: Great Tour, Wonderful Guide
data.text: My wife and I visited Slater Mill and thoroughly enjoyed the experience.  Our guide, Carl, was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic.  I would highly recommend a visit!

data.title: cool to see
data.text: Cool place to go to see how old Pawtucket used to operate. Interesting place to take the family, especially some younger/preteen kids, to show them how things used to get done.

data.title: Great Place to see in the daytime and nighttime
data.text: I've been to Slater Mill both in a regular tour and ghost tours.  I loved the place.  Being from a textile manufacturing background, Slater Mill was just a real education.  One might think that it was just awful that kids worked there, but at the time, it was perfectly legal, and no one was forced to work there.  The ghost tours are a great night out with your friends or spouse.  I've never felt anything malevolent or negative there, but I won't say there aren't any spirits in any of the mills.  I've always enjoyed my tours.  And finally, the Johnson brothers are a real hoot.

data.title: Interesting piece of important history
data.text: Pawtucket is loaded with old mills. It's nice to see this one restored and keeping the history of the area. You can see how the water was used in the mills for power. Interesting and quaint place by the river.

data.title: We learned a lot about a local attraction!
data.text: On a beautiful fall day, we decided to stop at an attraction that we've driven by for years.  We had to wait for a tour guide, but we received an information-laden 90 minute tour.  We saw the three buildings of the original Slater Mill, birth of the Industrial Revolution in the U.S.  We saw numerous old machines and tools. The mill is located on the river with a waterfall-a lovely site where they were setting up for a wedding ceremony that evening.

data.title: Who Knew?
data.text: Our guide was very informative. I didn't realize there were 3 buildings on the site. Lots of history in such a compact place. The setting is quaint and actually peaceful, in the garden and alongside the river waterfall.

data.title: Vacation
data.text:
Katherine gave us an excellent tour. She demonstrated vast knowledge about the history of the Mill. She presented the history in a very fun and interesting way. Really enjoyed learning about the history and about the people  that worked here.

At the visitors center the volunteer that worked there that morning provided us with a lot of helpful information. Highly recommend the video that is shown there before touring the Mill.

data.title: What a surprise
data.text: I have lived in RI my whole life and have never been here.  What a wonderful tour and historical place to visit.  A must see!

data.title: Definite Must See for Industrial Revolution History Buffs .. Great Tour/Great Docent
data.text: I found out more about the coming of the Industrial Revolution to the US during this tour than ever studying history in school. The docent was very knowledgeable about the history of the time as well as the family that ran Slaters Mill and Sylvanus Brown house. the history of milling and working with fabric on an industrial scale in the US was born here. There was a lot of information to be absorbed and it would be better to come pre-armed with as much background prior to visiting Slater Mill.

user_location.name: New York, New York, United States

data.title: Industrial Revolution comes alive
data.text: This is a complex of 3 buildings. The Slater Mill is where you buy tickets for the tour and the gift shop.  The walking tour takes you into all 3 buildings.  The docent, Robin, made the history of the industrial revolution come alive.  She answered all of our questions and took her time to demonstrate how wool, flax, and cotton were made into thread.  If you don't want to go inside you can walk around the grounds at no charge.  Ask for the AAA discount for $1 off the tour. Afterward ask how to get to the Exchange St Cafe and have lunch. This is a local spot with the largest Chicken Cobb salad I've ever enjoyed.

data.title: Nice mill but wish there were more signs
data.text:
Was a nice mill and was free so hard to complain.  Was e way to occupy and hour.  We were there when the SAM fest was there which was just coincidence.  That probably made it a bit nicer since a few vendor stalls to look at it and music and food.

The equipment is very interesting,  there were 2 guides by the textile mill and 1 park ranger type guy by the water wheel.   They all spoke to us but there was no "guided tour" so I'm not sure what others referring to.  They were very knowledgeable but then others would come through and they would switch to speaking to them and we were left to look at equipment that we had to guess what it did.  

Some nice signs describing each piece of equipment would be a nice enhancement.

data.title: Excellent Tour
data.text: I grew up 45 minutes away and came on a field trip back in the fourth grade.  Was in RI for the weekend so I stopped by first thing on a Friday morning.  Had a private tour with Keith, who was very knowledgeable about the industrial revolution in the late 1700's.  All sorts of cool belt driven machinery, spinning equipment.  Spent an hour and a half (I'm an Engineer and Science teacher, so an hour might be adequate for most) before I had to leave to pick up someone at the train station.

data.title: Totally Underrated
data.text:
My wife and I visited Slater Mill Museum today.  It's essentially a complex of three buildings in Pawtucket, one of which was moved to the site (the Brown House).

The tour guides are exceptional.  They are enthusiastic about the historical significance of the location and open to all questions.  They say the current tour is 90 minutes on their site; our tour was between 60-90 and that was with the tour guide taking into account our interests as the tour progressed (my mother-in-law uses a loom in her home while I'm interested in mechanical engineering).

The only small criticism I have is that I asked where the steam engine would have been that would have been the backup to when there was no water.  Tour guide said that he didn't know, but that he had been asked before.  Find out, then. :D

Anyway, I believe the recent establishment of the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park will drive more visitors to the site.  It would be well worth their time to take the tour and learn about how some very significant seeds of the American industrial revolution were sown in Pawtucket.

Tip:  Be sure to ask for the AAA discount on the tour prices.

data.title: Great place to stop!
data.text: We decided to visit here on a rainy day.  What a great visit it was.  We were luck to have two very knowledgable tour guides, Keith took the first half and a young lady from Washington state took the last half.  Wish I could remember her name as it was great talking to someone from our home state.  They both knew the history of this fascinating place very well.  I was so impressed with all the history here.  The place seems to be set like it was back in the day when the mill was running.  This place is rich in history, great tour pricing and top notch staff.  I highly recommend this to anybody with any interest in the history here.

data.title: Who knew their was so much history in Pawtucket
data.text: Excellent guided tour of multiple buildings.  Got to see how some of the machinery works.  Learned a lot about RI history in the late 1700s and early 1800s.   Who knew that Slater's Mill was the birthplace of the American Industrial Revolution?  Geniuses designed and built the machinery and the mill.  Very interesting and well worth the visit.  Ample free parking.  BTW, the Blackstone Valley Visitor's Center is just across the street.

data.title: Very interesting
data.text: The tour guides were very knowledgeable and we found the tour to be very interesting. If you are into history this place is for you. The insidebof buildings are very warm in the summer months.

data.title: Awesome!!
data.text: Staff was friendly and knowlegable.  The tour was great for a history buff like myself.  I have young children and the guides interacted with them brilliantly!  They really did a wonderful job of keeping them into the tour, all while still delivering the knowledge I was there to gather.  The American Industrial Revolution started here, so don't miss out on this piece of history!

data.title: Great Tour😋😍
data.text: The tour was extremely fascinating. I'm only 14 so I my expectation was that I would be bored. I wasn't. The tour guide was friendly. He was very knowledgeable of what he was talking about. The tour was about an hour and a half. Sadly, we had a plane to catch so we had to rush the last part. The tour was extremely interactive. I would really recommend stopping here & if I come back to Rhode Island, this is where I would come!

data.title: MUSTSEE FOR HISTORY BUFFS!
data.text:
The most important spot for the start of industrial revolution in America. Beautiful spot on historic Blackstone River in downtown Pawtucket,RI   Easy access and plenty of free parking.

  The actual tour was a little of a letdown.The guide didn't tie the events together and didn't explain the importance of the mill throughout the country. She was probably just having a bad day.  Despite this, it was still worth the trip. Read up on a little history of the museum before you go.

data.title: field trip fun
data.text: Staff are enthusiastic.  Kids enjoyed the tour. I love to just walk by the waterfalls nearby.  Charming downtown history.
